parts.title: Overview

parts.body:
##Definition of types of motorcycle

Type of motorcycle | Definition
- | -
Moped | 50cc, max speed 30mph
Learner | up to 125cc, power output not exceeding 11 kiloWatt (kW)

##Moped

If you want to ride a moped at 16 you must:

- take your theory test
- have done your compulsory basic training (CBT)
- have a [provisional licence](/apply-for-your-first-provisional-driving-licence "Apply for your first provisional licence")

###If you have a car licence

If you got a car driving licence before 1 February 2001, you can ride a moped without doing CBT.

##Types of licence

###Direct access

Direct Access training allows you to ride any size of bike if:

- you're 21 or over, or you reach 21 before your 2-year restriction ends
- you've passed the theory test

####Taking the test

You have to take the practical test on a motorcycle with a power output of at least 35kW. 

If you're doing CBT as part of Direct Access, you can take all or part of the CBT on either a learner bike or a large bike.

To practice for the practical test on a larger bike you must:

- be accompanied at all times by an approved instructor on another bike and in radio contact
- wear fluorescent or reflective clothing
- follow all other provisional licence restrictions

###Accelerated access

Accelerated access allows you to ride any size of bike if:

- you're 21 or over, or you'll reach 21 before your 2-year 25kW restriction ends
- you've got the LIGHTER LICENCE THINGY????

You'll need to pass the accelerated access test on a motorcycle of at least 35 kW.

You can practice for the test on bikes over 25 kW but you must:

- be accompanied at all times by an approved instructor on another bike and in radio contact
- wear fluorescent or reflective clothing
- follow all other provisional licence restrictions

You'll revert to learner status while practicing on a motorcycle greater than 25 kW but if you fail it won't affect your existing licence.

###Full motorcycle licence

Type of full licence | Bike to take the test on | What you can ride
- | -
light motorcycle licence (A1) | he practical test must be taken on a bike of between 75 cc and 125 cc | any bike up to 125 cc and a power output of 11 kW
standard motorcycle licence (A) | to get the standard licence you have to pass a standard motorcycle licence (A), is obtained if the practical test is taken on a bike of over 120 cc but not more than 125 cc and capable of at least 100 kph | restricted for two years to riding a bike of up to 25 kW and a power/weight ratio not exceeding 0.16 kW/kg. After this you may ride any size of bike

##Sidecars

###Learning to ride

You can practice on a combination with a power/weight ratio not exceeding 0.16 kiloWatt/kilogram.

###Standard licence

You'll be restricted to a combination with the same power/weight ratio for 2 years.

###Direct or accelerated access

If you're 21 or over you can practice on a combination power/weight ratio over 0.16 kiloWatt/kilogram. You have to take the test on a solo bike (although physically disabled riders can use a combination).

*[CBT]: Compulsory basic training
parts.title: Which licence you need

parts.body:
##Helmet

You must wear a safety helmet when riding a motorcycle on the road. All helmets sold in the UK must comply with at least one of these:

- British Standard BS 6658:1985 and carry the [BSI (British Standards Institution)Kitemark](http://www.bsigroup.com/en/ProductServices/PPE/Impact-Protection/ BSI Kitemark information"){:rel="external"}
- UNECE Regulation 22.05
- any standard accepted by a member of the European Economic Area which offers a level of safety and protection equivalent to BS 6658:1985 and carry a mark equivalent to the BSI Kitemark

$! If you need glasses or contact lenses to read a number plate at the prescribed distance, you must wear them when you ride.$!

##Visors and goggles

If you wear a visor or goggles when you ride, your visors or goggles must comply with either:
a British Standard and display a [BSI Kitemark](http://www.bsigroup.com/en/ProductServices/PPE/Respiratory-Hearing-Eye/ "BSI Kitemark information"){:rel="external"}
a European standard which offers a level of safety and protection at least equivalent to the British Standard and carry a mark equivalent to the BSI Kitemark (ECE 22-05)

*[BSI]: British Standards Institution
